articles.headline: Larry Fink’s Bet on Saudi Oil Money Is Also His Latest E.S.G. Woe
articles.snippet: Mr. Fink finds himself on the back foot once again, with BlackRock appointing the head of the Saudi oil giant Aramco to its board. Analysts say the move is about money, not optics.
articles.abstract: Mr. Fink finds himself on the back foot once again, with BlackRock appointing the head of the Saudi oil giant Aramco to its board. Analysts say the move is about money, not optics.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Larry Fink, the chief executive of the giant asset manager BlackRock, has been broadcasting a message to corporate America: Environmental, social and governance goals should be core to how companies do business.

articles.headline: From Right-Hand Man to Critical Witness: Pence at Heart of Trump Prosecution
articles.snippet: Mike Pence is playing an extraordinary role in a historic criminal case against his onetime benefactor and current rival, whose angry supporters once threatened Mr. Pence’s life.
articles.abstract: Mike Pence is playing an extraordinary role in a historic criminal case against his onetime benefactor and current rival, whose angry supporters once threatened Mr. Pence’s life.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence’s remarkable transformation from Donald J. Trump’s most loyal lieutenant to an indispensable, if reluctant, witness for his prosecution became clear this week, when he emerged as perhaps the central character in a stinging indictment accusing the former president of a criminal conspiracy to overturn the 2020 election.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Astor and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: Debt Downgrade, Driven by Partisanship, Is Unlikely to Deter Borrowing
articles.snippet: Fitch’s credit-rating decision stemmed from concerns about America’s ability to govern itself, along with the nation’s growing debt load.
articles.abstract: Fitch’s credit-rating decision stemmed from concerns about America’s ability to govern itself, along with the nation’s growing debt load.
articles.lead_paragraph: The downgrade of the United States’ debt by a major ratings firm is a damning indictment of the country’s fractious politics and a blot on its financial record that is unlikely to be quickly erased. But many investors and analysts say it won’t affect the government’s ability to keep borrowing money.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Trump Indictment Leaves Alleged Co-Conspirators Facing Tough Choices
articles.snippet: The special counsel’s decision not to charge six people said to have played critical roles in the effort to keep Donald Trump in office seemed to give them a chance to cooperate with prosecutors. Some appear to be unwilling.
articles.abstract: The special counsel’s decision not to charge six people said to have played critical roles in the effort to keep Donald Trump in office seemed to give them a chance to cooperate with prosecutors. Some appear to be unwilling.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time Jack Smith, the special counsel, was brought in to oversee the investigation of former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election, the inquiry had already focused for months on a group of lawyers close to Mr. Trump.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer, Luke Broadwater and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Trump Election Charges Set Up Clash of Lies Versus Free Speech
articles.snippet: The indictment of former President Donald J. Trump over his efforts to retain power accuses him of conspiracies built on knowing falsehoods. His supporters say he is protected by the First Amendment.
articles.abstract: The indictment of former President Donald J. Trump over his efforts to retain power accuses him of conspiracies built on knowing falsehoods. His supporters say he is protected by the First Amendment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Running through the indictment charging former President Donald J. Trump with conspiring to overturn the 2020 election was a consistent theme: He is an inveterate and knowing liar.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Pastor or Traitor? Ukrainians Shun a Church Seen as a Kremlin Tool.
articles.snippet: The village parishioners’ decision to oust their priest reflects a broader push within Ukraine to reduce the influence of an Orthodox church that answers to Moscow.
articles.abstract: The village parishioners’ decision to oust their priest reflects a broader push within Ukraine to reduce the influence of an Orthodox church that answers to Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: For two decades, Ilya Solkan served as the parish priest in a tiny Ukrainian village outside the capital, Kyiv. He baptized babies, blessed marriages and conducted funerals. The Orthodox church stood at the heart of the village and Mr. Solkan was central to its life.
articles.byline: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii Shyvala

articles.headline: So What Do We Call Twitter Now Anyway?
articles.snippet: With Elon Musk’s rebranding of the app, is Twitter’s name really retired? What about tweets? We unravel the terminology puzzle.
articles.abstract: With Elon Musk’s rebranding of the app, is Twitter’s name really retired? What about tweets? We unravel the terminology puzzle.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a simple name change, Elon Musk has created confusion in social media.

articles.headline: Trump’s 2024 Campaign Seeks to Make Voters the Ultimate Jury
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump has long understood the stakes in the election: The courts may decide his cases, but only voters can decide whether to return him to power.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump has long understood the stakes in the election: The courts may decide his cases, but only voters can decide whether to return him to power.
articles.lead_paragraph: The indictment of former President Donald J. Trump on charges of conspiring to overthrow the 2020 election ensures that a federal jury will determine whether he is held accountable for his elaborate, drawn-out and unprecedented attempt to negate a vote of the American people and cling to power.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Is Good News Finally Good News Again?
articles.snippet: Economists had been wary of strong economic data, worried that it meant inflation might stay high. Now they are starting to embrace it.
articles.abstract: Economists had been wary of strong economic data, worried that it meant inflation might stay high. Now they are starting to embrace it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Good news is bad news: It had been the mantra in economic circles ever since inflation took off in early 2021. A strong job market and rapid consumer spending risked fueling further price increases and evoking a more aggressive response from the Federal Reserve. So every positive report was widely interpreted as a negative development.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: What Can You Do When A.I. Lies About You?
articles.snippet: People have little protection or recourse when the technology creates and spreads falsehoods about them.
articles.abstract: People have little protection or recourse when the technology creates and spreads falsehoods about them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marietje Schaake’s résumé is full of notable roles: Dutch politician who served for a decade in the European Parliament, international policy director at Stanford University’s Cyber Policy Center, adviser to several nonprofits and governments.
